maml:description.maml:para: Ends forcibly the SMB session.

The Close-SmbSession cmdlet forcibly ends the Server Message Block (SMB) session. This cmdlet may cause loss of data if the client for which session is being stopped has not flushed all of the file modifications back to the server before the session is ended.
Specifies the identifier (ID) that uniquely identifies the session that is being ended.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the client computer name from which the only sessions are returned.
Specifies the name of the user whose sessions are retrieved.
Specifies, in case of a share hosted by a Windows cluster, the name of the server which is hosting the sessions are retrieved.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the scope of the sessions being retrieved.
Specifies the input to this cmdlet. You can use this parameter, or you can pipe the input to this cmdlet.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Specifies the input object that is used in a pipeline command.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the client computer name from which the only sessions are returned.
Specifies the name of the user whose sessions are retrieved.
Specifies, in case of a share hosted by a Windows cluster, the name of the server which is hosting the sessions are retrieved.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Specifies the input object that is used in a pipeline command.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the scope of the sessions being retrieved.
Specifies the identifier (ID) that uniquely identifies the session that is being ended.
Specifies the input to this cmdlet. You can use this parameter, or you can pipe the input to this cmdlet.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: ---------------- Example 1: End an SMB session ----------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Close-SmbSession -SessionId 8813272891621 Confirm Are you sure you want to perform this action? Performing operation 'Close-Session' on Target '8813272891621'. [Y] Yes [A] Yes to All [N] No [L] No to All [S] Suspend [?] Help (default is "Y"): N

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command ends an SMB session.

command:example.maml:title: ------ Example 2: End an SMB session without confirmation ------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command ends an SMB session without user confirmation.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves information about the SMB sessions that are currently established between the SMB server and the associated clients.
The Get-SmbSession cmdlet retrieves basic information about the Server Message Block (SMB) sessions that are currently established between the SMB server and the associated clients.
Specifies the identifiers (IDs) that uniquely identify the sessions for which the information is retrieved.
Specifies the client computer name from which the only sessions are returned.
Specifies the name of the user whose sessions are retrieved.
Specifies the scope of the sessions being retrieved.
Specifies, in the case of a share hosted by a Windows cluster, the name of the server which is hosting the sessions is retrieved.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Indicates that sessions that are created and used internally are enumerated also.
Specifies the input to this cmdlet. You can use this parameter, or you can pipe the input to this cmdlet.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the client computer name from which the only sessions are returned.
Specifies the name of the user whose sessions are retrieved.
Specifies, in the case of a share hosted by a Windows cluster, the name of the server which is hosting the sessions is retrieved.
Indicates that sessions that are created and used internally are enumerated also.
Specifies the scope of the sessions being retrieved.
Specifies the identifiers (IDs) that uniquely identify the sessions for which the information is retrieved.
Specifies the input to this cmdlet. You can use this parameter, or you can pipe the input to this cmdlet.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

The `Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance` object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (`#`) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object. The MSFT_SmbSession object represents the sessions established between the SMB server and the associated clients.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves information about the SMB sessions that are currently established between the SMB server and the associated clients.

command:example.maml:title: ------ Example 2: Get information for a specific session ------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-SmbSession -SessionId 8813272891621 SessionId ClientComputerName ClientUserName NumOpens --------- ------------------ -------------- -------- 8813272891621 192.168.101.13 Contoso\Administrator 0

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves information about the SMB session identified as 8813272891621 that is currently established between the SMB server and the associated clients.

command:example.maml:title: --- Example 3: Get session information for a specific client ---
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-SmbSession -ClientComputerName "192.168.102.14" SessionId ClientComputerName ClientUserName NumOpens --------- ------------------ -------------- -------- 4415226380377 192.168.102.14 Contoso\Contoso-HV2$ 1 4415226380385 192.168.102.14 Contoso\Contoso-HV2$ 1 4415226380393 192.168.102.14 Contoso\Contoso-HV2$ 5 8813272891489 192.168.102.14 Contoso\Contoso-HV2$ 1 8813272891493 192.168.102.14 Contoso\Contoso-HV2$ 1 8813272891517 192.168.102.14 Contoso\Contoso-HV2$ 5

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves information about the SMB sessions that are currently established between the SMB server and the SMB client at the IP address 192.168.102.14.

command:example.maml:title: ------- Example 4: Get session information for a client -------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-SmbSession -ClientUserName "Contoso\Contoso-HV1$" SessionId ClientComputerName ClientUserName NumOpens --------- ------------------ -------------- -------- 8813272891441 192.168.101.13 Contoso\Contoso-HV1$ 1 8813272891449 192.168.101.13 Contoso\Contoso-HV1$ 1 8813272891457 192.168.101.13 Contoso\Contoso-HV1$ 1 8813272891461 192.168.101.13 Contoso\Contoso-HV1$ 1 8813272891469 192.168.101.13 Contoso\Contoso-HV1$ 5 8813272891581 192.168.102.13 Contoso\Contoso-HV1$ 1 8813272891585 192.168.102.13 Contoso\Contoso-HV1$ 1 8813272891609 192.168.102.13 Contoso\Contoso-HV1$ 3 8813272891613 192.168.101.13 Contoso\Contoso-HV1$ 2

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves information about the SMB sessions that are currently established between the SMB server and the SMB client that has the user name Contoso\Contoso-HV1$.

command:example.maml:title: --------- Example 5: Get all information for a session ---------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-SmbSession -SessionId 8813272891441 | Select-Object -Property * ClientComputerName : 192.168.101.13 ClientUserName : Contoso\Contoso-HV1$ ClusterNodeName : Contoso-FS1 Dialect : 3.00 NumOpens : 1 ScopeName : Contoso-FS SecondsExists : 45346 SecondsIdle : 33 SessionId : 8813272891441 TransportName : PSComputerName : CimClass : ROOT/Microsoft/Windows/SMB:MSFT_SmbSession CimInstanceProperties : {ClientComputerName, ClientUserName, ClusterNodeName, Dialect...} CimSystemProperties : Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimSystemProperties

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves all of the information about the SMB session identified as 8813272891441 that are currently established between the SMB server and the SMB client.
